description: Alaska Constitution provisions relevant to child welfare and family rights.
copyright: Project Milk Carton 501(c)(3) - All Rights Reserved

relevant_provisions.name: Search and Seizure
relevant_provisions.text: The right of the people to be secure in their persons, houses and other property, papers, and effects, against unreasonable searches and seizures, shall not be violated. No warrants shall issue, but upon probable cause, supported by oath or affirmation, and particularly describing the place to be searched, and the persons or things to be seized.
relevant_provisions.application_to_cps: CPS removal of a child from the home constitutes a seizure that must meet Fourth Amendment standards. Alaska courts have interpreted this provision to provide greater protection than the federal Fourth Amendment in certain contexts, particularly regarding privacy expectations.

key_cases.case_name: A.L.J. v. State, Dep't of Health & Soc. Servs.
key_cases.relevance: Addresses due process requirements in child removal and custody proceedings

relevant_provisions.name: Due Process
relevant_provisions.text: No person shall be deprived of life, liberty, or property, without due process of law. The right of all persons to fair and just treatment in the course of legislative and executive investigations shall not be infringed.
relevant_provisions.application_to_cps: Parents have a fundamental liberty interest in the care, custody, and management of their children. Termination of parental rights requires clear and convincing evidence. The Alaska Constitution's due process clause has been interpreted to require procedural protections in child welfare proceedings including notice, opportunity to be heard, and right to counsel.

key_cases.case_name: A.A. v. State, Dep't of Family & Youth Servs.
key_cases.relevance: Discusses fundamental right of parents to raise children and due process protections in termination proceedings

key_cases.case_name: S.A. v. State, Dep't of Health & Soc. Servs., Office of Children's Servs.
key_cases.relevance: Addresses standard of proof and due process in parental rights termination

relevant_provisions.name: Equal Rights and Opportunities
relevant_provisions.text: This constitution is dedicated to the principles that all persons have a natural right to life, liberty, the pursuit of happiness, and the enjoyment of the rewards of their own industry; that all persons are equal and entitled to equal rights, opportunities, and protection under the law; and that all persons have corresponding obligations to the people and to the State.
relevant_provisions.application_to_cps: Provides equal protection guarantees similar to the federal Fourteenth Amendment. Parents must be treated equally in child welfare proceedings without discrimination based on protected characteristics. Alaska courts have interpreted this provision broadly.
relevant_provisions.federal_parallel: U.S. Const. amend. XIV, § 1 (Equal Protection Clause)

relevant_provisions.name: Right to Privacy
relevant_provisions.text: The right of the people to privacy is recognized and shall not be infringed. The legislature shall implement this section.
relevant_provisions.application_to_cps: Alaska is one of few states with an explicit constitutional right to privacy. This provision provides greater protection than federal constitutional privacy rights. It protects family autonomy and parental decision-making, though it must be balanced against the state's parens patriae interest in child protection. Privacy rights extend to family relationships and childrearing decisions.
relevant_provisions.federal_parallel: U.S. Const. amend. XIV (implicit privacy through substantive due process)

key_cases.relevance: Seminal case establishing robust privacy protections under Alaska Constitution, broader than federal protections

relevant_provisions.name: Trial by Jury
relevant_provisions.text: The right of trial by jury shall be secured to all and remain inviolate. The legislature may provide for a jury of not less than twelve in civil cases and that the verdict may be by concurrence of three-fourths of the jury.
relevant_provisions.application_to_cps: While parental rights termination proceedings are generally considered civil rather than criminal, parents have due process rights to a fair hearing. Alaska does not typically require jury trials in termination proceedings, but ensures judicial fact-finding with appropriate safeguards.

relevant_provisions.name: Freedom of Speech
relevant_provisions.text: Every person may freely speak, write, and publish on all subjects, being responsible for the abuse of that right.
relevant_provisions.application_to_cps: Parents have the right to speak freely about their cases, subject to court orders protecting confidentiality. This provision may protect parental advocacy and criticism of CPS actions, though it must be balanced against child privacy interests and court confidentiality rules.

relevant_provisions.name: Right to Remedy
relevant_provisions.text: The courts shall be open and every person shall have a remedy for injury to person, property or reputation.
relevant_provisions.application_to_cps: Parents who have been wrongfully subjected to CPS actions have the right to seek remedies through the courts. This provision ensures access to judicial remedies for constitutional violations in child welfare proceedings.

relevant_provisions.name: Prohibition on Cruel and Unusual Punishment
relevant_provisions.text: Excessive bail shall not be required, nor excessive fines imposed, nor cruel and unusual punishments inflicted.
relevant_provisions.application_to_cps: While primarily applicable to criminal cases, this provision may be invoked in extreme child welfare cases where state actions are punitive in nature or effect. Termination of parental rights, while civil, has been described as the 'death penalty' of family law.
